content: so i took this mini that a sponsor sent me
and i did cruel and unusual things to it turned it into something they definitely
were not intending it to be for and uh well i hope they're not
mad
hey guys welcome back to blackmagic craft so wicked foundations you may
remember them because i did a video for them previously where i painted their
very cool dional beast miniature that kickstarter
has long since passed but they're moving into the actual production and
distribution phase of the models and they're looking to bring some
attention to it for late pledges and they sent me an even cooler and even
bigger miniature it's a d d monster
i turned it into not a dmd monster they've got a whole book included with
this campaign with fifth edition compatible stats for
these monsters but i went full nergo on it
this model is called the stragore strigori strigor strigori streegor
the word is strigor the strigor thanks charles this strigor mini
despite being entirely up my alley in terms of its style as is ended up
being my demon prince of nergal so as i stared at
the sprue pre-assembly i heavily contemplated what
direction to take it was really tempting to just
build him and paint him in a similar way to how he looked in their book because
well the artwork is amazing and i do really
love the way he looks there
but since my mind is currently really focused on building up my death guard
army for 40k well i couldn't help myself this guy was
gonna be my demon prince my plan was to assemble him without much modification
and simply paint him in a more of a nurgle
color scheme now this is a big model and it took a
bit of time to assemble i took my time cleaning up the flash and
making sure everything fit together really well this is actually my favorite
part of working with plastic models for some reason
i get a lot of satisfaction out of building them and on a model of this
size it's actually not that annoying to sand off
mold lines because you can actually get your tools into all
the little nooks and crannies come to think of it i've never built a
model this big before so it was a bit of uncharted territory
for me thankfully all of the various parts went together really easily
and had big slotted connections so nothing needed pinning and it was all
held in place really securely i'm usually not patient enough when
building models to use plastic cement because it's not instant you gotta like
hold the pieces while the glue does its thing i usually just turn
to the weaker choice of super glue but because i didn't have to hold everything
in place for ages or pin anything i was able to go with it on this build
which was gonna make it a lot more durable none of the parts are ever gonna
fall off this big boy but one challenge with a model this size
was finding a way to hold him while painting
it was tempting to just mount him to the base but
i really wanted to paint the two things separately so i managed to hot glue them
to a large pill bottle and thanks to the big chunky keying
pieces on the feet and actually held it really well
but i gotta say it was almost comical to me to have such a
big model on a pill bottle like this he had a lot of gaps on joints that needed
filling and i think this is par for the course
on large plastic models but i do want to point out that
this sprue that i received is not the final version that will be shipped to
backers this was the first in a batch of production samples that they received
for quality control from the factory and was
complete with any initial flaws that need correcting before the final
versions are shipped out but most of the gaps on him were pretty reasonable
and just needed a tiny bit of milliput there were some larger gaps that
needed a heavier fix and some sculpting to blend them
the part i struggled with the most was the gaps on the hair this is always a
problematic area when there's a seam on models
because the worst gaps were in this area it did require a lot more work
i tried to sculpt in some hair to kind of blend it but
i really didn't do that great of a job the other issue with the first
production sample is that there were some areas of the hair where the detail
was very soft this made the task of blending my
milliput even harder then i also hid the seams on the base
with milliput which was a pointless waste of time because i immediately
decided to add more texture to the base by
applying some vallejo ground cover this would help it match the other
models in my army where i'd use the same stuff
but this was just the beginning of my descent into madness
on this base so this base has some sculptural details that run
off and onto the rim this is pretty neat and makes for a really dynamic base
and it would look really cool in a game of d but i got it in my head that it
needed a plain black rim to match the rest of my army
so this is where i really went crazy i decided to
cut off these parts this was not the easiest thing to do
as cutting and sanding plastic like this tends to cause a fair bit of melting
when using a rotary tool i did manage to get it pretty decent
though but because the plastic melts before it
sounds smooth i really couldn't get it close to
perfect i figured i'd apply a layer of milliput and let that cure and then sand
it really smooth but the milliput that i had mixed up
before was already starting to harden and get
kind of chunky so it made it really difficult to apply
it was as i was mixing a fresh batch that i decided
maybe millipub wasn't the answer and chose to clean it off and switch to
modeling paste this stuff could be applied a lot more easily
and a lot more smoothly and could be easily sanded once dry
i did this and like it was okay but it wasn't perfect
it really needed a veneer so i cut a strip of construction paper and super
glued it in place why didn't i use a strip of styrene you
ask well the answer is simple i didn't have
any it would have been the perfect solution here and honestly
a lot of the problems that i regularly face when working on bases for models or
dioramas could be solved with a bit of styrene
one of these days i will finally get around to stocking my
shop with some but not this day no on this day i would
instead harden the paper with super glue this works surprisingly well though and
i really can't complain with the end result like
all things considered is pretty decent with that done i took
the model outside to prime yeah i have a spray booth in my shop but
with the weather so nice i might as well take advantage of it and
do as much work outside as i can and hey this gave me the perfect opportunity to
film myself doing something entirely out of frame of
the camera because like it was so bright outside i
i couldn't see the screen and i'm an idiot
sorry about that i really need to hire a camera person
after priming i really didn't like the way the areas of the hair was looking
my millipede blends looked like they looked dumb
now before i go totally off the rails on this model i'm gonna take a second to
tell you a little bit about the campaign that it's from so this model comes from
wicked foundation's tales of terror collection this
collection includes a series of highly creepy
and weird plastic miniatures these are really really weird
in the best possible way they're not your standard d
d fair so if you like me are into more bizarre style monsters and foes
well this is the place for you while the monsters aren't traditional d d
style all pledge packages do come with a fifth edition
d d compatible pdf beast jerry that includes stat blocks as well as cool
artwork and lore this is really gonna help you interject
these weird creatures into your game each set of miniatures also comes with a
unique and themed playmat to use for an encounter while running these bizarre
creatures while these models are designed and
intended for d there's absolutely no reason you can't use them
in other games whatever game you play they might be a good fit maybe you want
to use some of the weirder ones as demons in your warhammer armies like
i am or maybe you want to use them in a lovecraftian horror game
it's really up to you i'll put a link in the video description to the page where
you can jump in on the late pledges before these
fully hit manufacturing and distribution now let's see me fix a tiny problem with
a sledgehammer since i was going to be using this model
in a crusty nurgle army i figured i'd dive a little deeper into
the world of blanchitsu modeling why not add some texture paste onto the
hair to create some weird fungal textures to hide my poor
hair sculpting that worked out pretty good so i took it further
and i grabbed some of the vaio texture paste with the larger pumice in it
and i started adding even more textural buildups
my hope was that this would look like some kind of fungal rot or
growth on the finished product you know that saying
less is more well i really didn't think that here i
really really didn't keep that idea in mind
if something's looking good i might as well add more right
i went crazy overboard and put the stuff all over the model
for better or worse it's uh well it's what i did but why stop there
why not add more layers of texture with some foliage
sheets normally i'd never do something like
this before painting i've never tried anything like it but why the
hell not inspired by various 28 style paint jobs where things like
flocking and grass tuffs are applied before paints
i just went for it with the hopes that it would look cool and
and all over airbrush paint job would make it look really
neat and awesome hell might as well add some more to the base too
just to see how it would look painting it afterwards once it all dried i primed
it all again and moved on to airbrushing for this guy my
approach was almost entirely acrylic inks through an
airbrush and i used a combination of browns and greens that i mixed myself to
get some unique colors i started with a sort of sepia type
brown and used it more from below now reviewing
the footage here i really like the way he looked at this
point in this more brown tone and i sort of regret the green editions that i
had in a moment but the idea was to look like a nurgle demon and somehow
green seemed more fitting i meant to use the green in a
subtle way just to add overtones and highlights but
as was the theme of this build i went overboard
i tried to tone down the green a bit with another application of sepia ink
and this kind of worked after the ink dried i didn't do
too much more painting but i did dry brush on a little white to some of the
heavier areas of texture to kind of make it look like boils
this didn't really have a very strong effect and i kind of
regretted not adding some little small glass beads to the mix when i put it on
this would have made it look like big  balls to
match what you see on models like the pox walkers the only
other part of the model they got any paint was the mask
which i painted bronze followed by a verdigris wash
the final effect would be some nice gory liquid effects from the
gaping horror hole in his midsection i mixed up some uv resin with some inks
and a bit of contrast paint i wanted to go for a color that had that
look of decomposition which is why i went for more of a brownish orange than
say a bloody red in the end i don't think i got this
color quite right it was okay but probably would have looked better if
i had made it a little bit more translucent
this much tinted uv resin would never cure properly with my little flashlight
so thankfully this big guy just barely fit
into my bigger nail curing light i took them off the pill bottle and
glued him to his base i added some dry pigment powder to the
base not because i thought it needed it but because i had done so on some of the
other bases in my army and i wanted to try to enhance that
cohesiveness with a model that wasn't really meant for that army
i topped that off with a bit of leftover uv resin for good measure
i really felt like i'd be doing this model a disservice if i didn't add some
strings of goo and drips so i created some strands
with more uv resin this is a process that i find turns out
good about 50 of the time that i do it it's pretty
tricky to get them looking right and to get them thin and natural looking
because it was nearing the end of a very long day
and the end of the project i unfortunately rushed this step
which i really should not have in the end it looked okay but
really the strands were far too big and looked more like intestines spilling out
than they looked like drips of liquid not ideal but i'm not gonna lose much
sleep over it it is one of those situations though where
i would have been better off calling it a day and saving this task for the next
morning with a fresh set of eyes but this whole build i kind of went out
like a madman why was i in such a rush well in all
honesty it's because the next day i would be playing my first game of 40k
using my new nurgle army and because my collection
had just started this army was really small and
i really needed this demon prince model to get a sufficient power level up
enough even for a small game this guy may have been meant as a creepy
d d monster but for me he's gonna be a
disgusting demon prince of nergal looking out over a sea of pox walkers
and plague marines i think he fits into the style well
enough and it'll be a pretty intimidating model on the game table
he's seriously huge thankfully this base size is only slightly bigger than it
should be for the model i'm using him in place of
so what do you guys think did i ruin this sponsor's model kind of a
little bit i really went a bit nuts adding a bunch of
crud to him that covered up quite a bit of the original
model but that's okay with me he's exactly what i need for my nurgle
army and i like him just fine
if you want to pick him up or check out the other models in the series again
i'll put a link to the wicked foundation's tales of terror
late pledge kickstarter in the video description below if you
like this video hit the like button let me know your thoughts in the
comments section if you need to pick up any modeling supplies for yourself
please use blackmagicraft.ca there have my central equipment page
where i list all the stuff that i use and shopping via that page really helps
fund the production of these videos the other
way you can help fund the production of these videos and ensure i can keep
making them and sharing them with you guys is by supporting the channel on
patreon by joining the blackmagic craft fellowship you really helped me out
i really appreciate it i'd love to have you as the newest member
that's it for this week guys as a filming
i'm gonna play my first game of 40k using my new army tonight i'm really
excited about it see you guys next week
